# Meta.md

# World Meta
#### What is World Meta?
>Your World Meta is the basic principles of your worldbuilding project, a document to reference whenever you’re stuck with your worldbuilding, novel or campaign. As your world grows, your Foundation may evolve, but you shouldn’t violate your basic principles.

#### Why should I use World Meta?
>World Meta helps protect you against a lot of things!
>-   If you get **stuck**, or **lose motivation**, referencing your meta will get you back on track.
>-   World Meta also acts as a **sense check** for your world, ensuring that what you’re adding makes sense with your larger creative vision
>-   World Meta is a great springboard to start your world from, and also a great source of inspiration when you want to open up a new part of your world - a new solar system, continent, region or plane.

#### How do I fill this out?
>**Keep your answers brief**, just simple sentences and paragraphs. You’ll be referencing this document a lot, and brief prose will help you find answers quickly!
>
If you have **additional ideas** you don’t want to lose, add them to your World Anvil notebook, or make brief articles using the purple button at the bottom right! You can expand these ideas later.
>
Reference previous answers to help you answer the next question! For example, if your **audience experience** was “a raw, prehistoric-feeling world” then choose a very volcanically active geography, and add dinosaurs or wooly mammoths!

>-   For example, if your **Motivation** is “to recapture your love of Saturday morning cartoons”, you might want to choose a superhero genre in the **genre section**.
>-   For example, if your **audience experience** was “a raw, prehistoric-feeling world” then choose a very volcanically active geography, and add dinosaurs or wooly mammoths!

#### How do I use this later?
>Whenever you’re stuck, or just wondering what to do next, come back to these meta documents.
>-   Need inspiration for a new quest or subplot? Dig into your genre, or even your current affairs for inspiration!
>-   Can’t decide what something should look like? Refer back to your themes, your tone, or your inspiration board.
>-   What should you build next? From here, especially the scene section, you’ll get ideas about organizations, nations, religions, traditions, languages and more.
>-   Feeling lost? Revisit your motivation and your Hook - they’ll get you back to the core of what you’re doing, and why!

## Scope
>**Keep track of WHY you're creating**
Stay on track and make your world, campaign or novel the very best it can be! It all starts with a little motivation...

### What is your motivation for building this world?
>Decide what the world is being built for, and what it means to you - that way, it’ll be fit for purpose!

### What are you hoping to get out of it?
>Knowing what you want from your worldbuilding project will help keep you on track when you get tired or stuck. Are you creating for a novel or a D&D campaign? What kind of experience do you want your audience to have?

### What is the hook or unique selling point of you world? What makes it different?
>This is the core of your idea, the hook that draws you - and hopefully your players and readers - into the setting of the world.
>
When we say “Unique” we really mean “special to you”. As long as you’re excited about the concept, that’s enough. Don’t feel like you have to reinvent the wheel and come up with something 100% original.

## Theme
>**Instill clarity and consistency to your storytelling.**
From the darkest dungeon to the brightest rainbow, choose the look and feel of your world, and how noble (or grim) your heroes’ fates will be!

### What's the genre of your world?
>Knowing the genre(s) and general technology/magic level will help you set expectations about your world, and keep your world feeling cohesive.

### How does the world feel (player/reader experience)?
>Do you want your world to feel mystical, or terrifying - or both? Should your audience be afraid or moved, filled with wanderlust or wonder? Awed by the past, or by the future? Your world will have a general feel to it, even if the specifics of tone vary from story to story.

### What is the character agency level like?
>Character agency describes how much power the main characters or player characters have to change the world, and how long-lasting that change might be.\*
>
These motifs are a great way to help reinforce the feeling of your world, despite the different pacing and mood of locations or scenes within your story or campaign. They do not need to feature in every single session or scene.

### What is the tone of your world?
>Is your world  

>- **dark** (e.g. Game of Thrones, Battlestar Galactica, The Witcher)  
>- or **bright** (e.g. original Star Trek, the Princess Bride, My Little Pony),  
>- or **somewhere in the middle** (e.g. StarGate, Harry Potter, Shannara Chronicles)? 
>
How pleasant or difficult is it to live there, in general? Do horrible or wondrous things happen to ordinary people?

### What are the recurring themes which reinforce the genre, tone and feel of your world?
>A few recurring themes can help anchor your audience in your tone and genre, and establish your hook. What three motifs/scenes/themes capture the world you’re trying to create?*
>
*(give three to five examples)

## Focus
> **Focus the subjects you will be expanding on.**
>
*Choose three to five focal points of your world to focus your worldbuilding on.**  
It’s a sad truth of worldbuilding that you can’t create EVERYTHING! Decide a few focus points* you want to expand on. This will give the impression that your world is very deep and detailed. You can always expand more areas later!
>
**Examples might include (this list is not exhaustive!)**
>-   Government Presence
>-   Rule Of Law
>-   Social Services
>-   Economic Strength
>-   Wealth Distribution
>-   Agriculture And Trade
>-   Race Relations
>-   Class Relations
>-   Gender Relations
>-   Sexual Orientation Relations
>-   Military Influence
>-   Religious Influence
>-   Technology Influence
>-   Arts And Culture Influence

## Drama
> **Adding drama is the way to put your world in motion**
>
*Add 5 points of drama to your world. *
Drama is the current affairs of your world - what’s happening right now. You can use one or two of them for your main plot line, but the rest are just there to create the impression of a larger world in motion. Drama is a great source not only of side quests and B plots, but also of background dialogue!  
>  
If you need to add more, use this expanded section

### Expanded Drama
>Fill here any other minor drama points that are either local or personal to the characters / party and/or story you are currently exploring.


## Scene
>**Describe your world's basic properties**
Make your setting feel unique with strange geographical quirks, bizarre weather, and deep magic.

### What are the fundamental differences in the natural laws of your world compared to Earth? (Rules of the world)
>Does your world have magic or altered gravity, midichlorians or psionics? Are the gods wandering the world? Nail down your world’s natural laws now - they will have fundamental repercussions on everything else in your world!
>
*Make sure you sense-check with your previous answers - if your genre is hard sci-fi, you might not want to introduce magic, for example.

### How did this world come to be? (Cosmology)
>The dominant religion, The Children of the Suns, believes that the world is the child of the twin suns, La and Tho. In reality, the world was intentionally created from a nebula by aliens who will be back to check on it someday...
>
Write how your world ACTUALLY came to be - was it born from an egg, created by a god, or sneezed into being? You can add the prevalent in-world belief if you like. Just one paragraph on this - don't go full Silmarillion!

### What the geography of your world look like? Does your geography have any special properties or features?
>This should be a generic vision of your geography. Is your world full of volcanos and lava flows or floating islands? Is it an ice planet, or a desert waste? Is it a planet-city like Coruscant? Is it bio-diverse or all the same?
>
From winters which last decades (Game of Thrones, G.R.R. Martin) to moons which throw destructive spores (World of Pern, Anne MacCaffery ), extraordinary geographical features can add character and challenges to your world. What are the fundamental truths of the physical geography of your world?
>
**Remember to refer back to your genre, tone and motifs in your Foundation! They’ll give you a tonne of inspiration for this.**

### What is the initial size of your active seeing?
>What is the initial scale* of your active storytelling space? An island, a region or a continent, for example?
>
Defining your initial active setting doesn’t mean your players or main characters can’t go elsewhere! But it does help you create a starting point which feels rich and alive.
>
Remember this will be affected by the genre! If you’re playing a Star Trek campaign, you’ll be exploring different planets, so an active area might be a solar system or a cluster of systems.

## People
>**Explore the impact of sentience in your world**
Breathe life into your world with great fallen empires, forgotten cities and lost civilizations. Add conflict and drama with the struggles and politics of today.

### Who used to live here, and what's their history?
>Write max. 1 paragraph on each lost civilization that was active in the area. Remember you can always add more later, which have not yet been discovered!
>
This is where the unknown mysteries come from, and a great source of dungeons, secrets, adventures, unique items and more. Also makes your world feel living and established. If you want your world to feel brand new and unsettled, write instead about the geological history of your world - the fossils that people will find.

### Which species/cultures live here now and what's their history?
>Keep it brief! A paragraph is enough for the major civilizations. A sentence is plenty for any minor cultures which might be part of the adventure. Add other cultures not in your main storytelling area in one additional sentence.

### What do they need, and what do they need from each other?
>For each group, limit your answer to one paragraph, and remember to include one sentence on their opinion of "others". Detail other cultures not in your main storytelling area in one additional sentence.
>
For example, who are they? What do they look like? Start with a little bit of history, and then turn that into an attitude and a need.

## Inspiration
>**Stay inspired and focused, create an anchor to reinvigorate your passion**
Inspiration, inspiration, inspiration! What movies, music, art and ideas have inspired your world setting?
>
Collect all the different media references together here, to create a grand library of inspiration tailored to your world. Come back whenever you want to recapture the mood or get inspired for a new writing sprint!
>
Make sure you add notes to detail WHAT in each piece of media inspires you. Marking what you love about your references will help you when you come back later!
>
For example, for a “treasure seeking amongst the stars” setting, you might add both “Indiana Jones” and “Star Trek”. You love the dungeon-delving aspect of Indiana Jones, but your world is more like Star Trek from a genre and technology standpoint.

# Book\Silvermeet - 01.md

During a lonely night at the village of [[Silvermeet]], south of [[Kingscross]] and the [[Blackrock Highlands]], while the wind howled and the pines cracked from its movement, the air was humid and smelled like moss after a full day's rain, and the tiny-soaked birds now chirped atop an old tavern's roof made of straws and lumber, an old man walked into the warm, comforting ambient from the harsh, winter-cold streets. Little did he know, that would be his last day as the man he knew himself to be.

# Elda
###### Location Type: [[Settlement Types#Capital|Capital]]
![[Elda.jpg]]

### Parent Location
The parent location defines in which locations area this location is included. If your location is a mountain range the parent location can be a planetary body, a continent or an island depending on how granularly you want to "nest" your locations.

### Founding Date
The time that the settlement was founded

### Date that Became a Ruin (if any)
The point in time that this settlement became a ruin. If anything is added to this the settlement will be marked as "ruined".

### Ruler / Owner
If this is a landmark, a settlement or a building this can be the actual owner of the structure.

### Owning Rank
Which rank/title has ownership over this location? (i.e. Earldom under Earl, City under Mayor etc)

### Owning Organization
Cities, Guilds, Kingdoms, Religious organizations can own territories, buildings or whole cities. Define here which of your world's organizations claims ownership over this location.

### Organizations Contesting Ownership of the Location

### Alternative Name(s)

### Population
The population of a settlement is defined as the number of permanent citizens accounted for during the settlement's last census. It does not take into consideration itenerant visitors like travelling merchants, standing armies etc.

### Inhabitants Demonym

### Demographics
Demographics are all about how the population of the settlement is distributed amongst different species, ethnicities, wealth classes, professions etc.

### Government
Here you can describe the way that the settlement is run. The laws, taxation and organization of the machine which is responsible to keep this settlement alive.

### Infrastructure
Infrastructure: What have the entrepreneurial spirits of this settlement built? Examples include watermills and windmills, sewers, courtyards, blast furnaces, roads, bridges, shipyards etc.

### Wards & Districts

### Assets
Equipment, stores, valuables etc.

### Defences
The defences of the settlement are the arrays and layers of infrastructure that make sure that the inhabitants and wealth of the settlement is safe. Palisades, walls, moats, towers, raised bridges etc. and their specifications can be described here.

### Industry & Trade
Describe here the way that the settlement stays afloat. What do its inhabitants do for a living. Which are the most important imports, exports and manufacturing taking place in the settlement.

### Guilds & Factions
Settlements, from the smallest town to the most thriving of metropolicies is moved one direction or another by the organizations which affect its politics and financial development. Describe here which are these factions for this settlement.

### History
A short description of the history of the settlement. Don't forget that you can add all the important events at the settlement's timeline by creating a timeline and attaching it to the article.

### Tourism
What sort of people visit this location as tourists, what are they eager to see and visit and experience? Where do they stay during their time there.

### Architecture
Which is the style of architecture used in this settlement? Which is the stone or wood used for the walls of its buildings? How do people traditionally adorn their structures (e.g. white picket fences, whitewashed walls with ocean blue roofs or brightly coloured door)

### Geography
Describe the location's geographic features. Is the terrain a plain, a mountain or rolling hills? Does it have access to fresh water via a river or a lake? Is it at the edge of a sea or an ocean? You can also talk about the views and natural beauty of the location.

### Natural Resources
Wood from the forests, grain from the fields, sheep in the rolling hills and metals and stone from the bowels of the earth. Natural resources define all the assets that can be found by prospectors, or can be exploited by the population living in, or near by this location

Localizada na costa do [[Kesh Desert]], Varatha é uma cidade costeira construída ao redor do Rio Varathos e com vista para a Baía dos Vitrais.

Varatha é uma cidade antiga fundada na primeira metade da 4ª era, anterior ao estabelecimento do Império Kesh. Ela se destaca como um marco histórico e cultural dentro do Deserto de Kesh, refletindo séculos de civilização e conhecimento.

Varatha é uma cidade autônoma dentro do Império Keshen. O príncipe Abit, um androsfinge imortal disfarçado de nobre élfico, governa Varatha com autonomia concedida pelo Imperador Darion Ajakx.

Varatha é o último bastião da civilização antes que o [[Kesh Desert]] dê lugar às [[Lost Plains]]. At No delta do Rio Varathos, perto da Floresta Anciã, a população de Varatha vem de diversas culturas, predominantemente humanos, draconatos e elfos.

Varatha opera sob uma estrutura governamental única devido à parceria do Príncipe Abit com o Império Kesh. Abit, um androsphinx disfarçado, tem sido o governante de Varatha por milênios, impondo estabilidade por meio de força e sabedoria. Enquanto a cidade segue as leis do império na maioria dos aspectos, ela tem privilégios de autogoverno em áreas como comércio e leis locais, uma condição negociada com o Imperador Darion.

O príncipe Abit, como governante de Varatha, trabalha em estreita colaboração com o Conselho da Cidade, que serve como um órgão consultivo com autoridade sobre regulamentações em andamento. As cadeiras do conselho são divididas entre guildas, templos e a academia. Os representantes cumprem mandatos de cinco anos sem reeleição consecutiva, e o presidente da assembleia é nomeado por Abit para um mandato de dez anos, elegível para apenas uma nomeação.

### Notable Residents

1. **Harbormaster Telvin of the Navigator’s Guild**
    
    - **Role**: Leader of the Navigator’s Guild
    - **Description**: Telvin is the skilled Harbormaster in charge of Varatha’s docks and a respected member of the Navigator's Guild. Experienced in both desert and sea navigation, Telvin ensures the efficient movement of goods through Varatha’s harbor. He is known for his no-nonsense attitude and meticulous organizational skills, and he often personally oversees the arrival and departure of key shipments. His loyalty to Varatha and his ability to manage both land and water trade routes have made him invaluable.
2. **Shadowmaster Veric of the Thieves’ Guild**
    
    - **Role**: Leader of the Thieves' Guild
    - **Description**: Veric is a cunning and resourceful rogue who leads Varatha’s Thieves’ Guild from the shadows of Tumbleweed Village. Known only as “Shadowmaster” by the guild, Veric has established an extensive network within Varatha's underground, specializing in smuggling, especially in contraband Dragon Glass. He has a reputation for being elusive and ruthless, maintaining strict loyalty within his ranks. Veric’s connections make him a powerful figure in Varatha’s underworld, and rumors circulate that he has ties to Rakshasa families hidden among the city’s less savory residents.
3. **Archmage Nalia, Headmistress of the Academy of Dancing Lights**
    
    - **Role**: Leader of the Academy of Dancing Lights
    - **Description**: Archmage Nalia is the headmistress of the Academy of Dancing Lights, overseeing the study of Divination, Evocation, and Transmutation. Known for her brilliance and dedication to magical scholarship, Nalia’s teachings have shaped generations of Varatha’s wizards. She is often present at council meetings and is instrumental in the city’s arcane protection efforts. Although strict, Nalia encourages creativity and intellectual freedom among her students, fostering a culture of learning and experimentation.
4. **Elder Kaelen, Leader of the Followers of Ahmis**
    
    - **Role**: Leader of the Followers of Ahmis
    - **Description**: Elder Kaelen is a reclusive and wise sage, the leader of the Followers of Ahmis, an esoteric faction dedicated to preserving ancient knowledge related to Ahmis, the god of the void. He is one of the few with knowledge of Varatha’s oldest history and maintains a low profile, rarely seen by the public. Kaelen’s followers believe that forgotten relics and secrets lie hidden in the sands beyond Varatha, and under his guidance, they seek these remnants while maintaining the Vault of Ahmis. He is rumored to be in possession of ancient texts, some of which are said to hold powerful void magic.
5. **Captain Alrek of the Varathan Rangers**
    
    - **Role**: Captain of the Varathan Rangers
    - **Description**: Captain Alrek is a seasoned and respected leader of the Varathan Rangers, known for his tactical acumen and fierce loyalty to Varatha. With extensive training in desert combat and urban defense, Alrek commands respect among his troops. He is dedicated to keeping the city safe, often leading patrols himself, and is known for his strong moral compass. Under his leadership, the Rangers have become one of the most disciplined forces in the Keshen Empire.
6. **Captain Elira of the Principal Guard**
    
    - **Role**: Captain of the Principal Guard
    - **Description**: Captain Elira is the formidable leader of the Principal Guard, an elite force responsible for the direct protection of Prince Abit and key locations in Varatha. Known for her strict discipline and unwavering loyalty to Abit, Elira has trained her guards to be highly efficient, skilled in both defensive and offensive strategies. Her reputation for strategic brilliance has kept her and her guards a step ahead of threats, making her one of the most trusted figures in Varatha’s leadership.
7. **Dockmaster Grent of the Port District**
    
    - **Role**: In charge of Varatha's Docks
    - **Description**: Dockmaster Grent manages the day-to-day operations at Varatha’s docks, ensuring that goods move smoothly through the harbor. A gruff, no-nonsense individual with a deep understanding of Varatha’s trade needs, Grent is known for his efficiency and fair but firm handling of labor disputes. He works closely with Telvin from the Navigator’s Guild, ensuring that the docks run efficiently, even during peak trade seasons.

> [!cite] Organizações
>  
> ```dataview
> TABLE
> WHERE tipo = "organização" and contains(local, link(this.file.name))
> ```

- **The Glassmakers’ Guild**: Highly influential due to Varatha’s glassmaking industry, the Glassmakers’ Guild preserves techniques for creating stained glass and Dragon Glass, passed down through generations. They oversee all aspects of glass production, ensuring Varatha’s reputation as a center of exquisite craftsmanship.
    
- **The Alchemists’ Circle**: This guild comprises Varatha’s most skilled alchemists and herbalists. Their specialty lies in refining Dragon Glass and crafting rare compounds sourced from local and imported herbs. High Alchemist Ravax leads this circle, renowned for his expertise and dedication to alchemical mastery.
    
- **Merchant’s Guild**: Dominating trade within the city, the Merchant’s Guild is responsible for organizing the Great Market and overseeing large-scale trade operations in Varatha. The guild acts as an intermediary between the Keshen Empire’s traders and Varatha’s artisans, managing trade routes, prices, and taxes.
    
- **Navigator’s Guild**: Based in the Port District, the Navigator’s Guild manages Varatha’s docks and maritime trade operations, ensuring the safety of sea routes and assisting merchants in navigating the Stained Glass Bay. They also play a key role in organizing trade caravans and routes through the Kesh Desert.
    
- **Thieves’ Guild**: Operating discreetly from the Tumbleweed Village slums, the Thieves’ Guild has a strong influence over the city’s underground economy. Known for contraband trade, especially Dragon Glass smuggling, the guild is rumored to have ties with some Rakshasa families who control various underworld activities from the shadows.
    
- **Followers of Ahmis**: A secretive faction dedicated to the god of the void, Ahmis. Members seek to preserve and study ancient knowledge related to Ahmis, often convening in hidden locations within the city. Though few know the full extent of their activities, they are rumored to maintain links to the lost temples of Ahmis, including the elusive Vault of Ahmis.

### Infraestrutura
A infraestrutura de Varatha é sofisticada para uma cidade do deserto e um testamento de sua idade e prosperidade.
Ela apresenta:
- **Vidraria Avançada**: Central para sua reputação, Varatha tem suas fundições especializadas, famosas por produzir vitrais de alta qualidade e o premiado Vidro Draconico, que corta mais afiado que aço.
- **Gestão da Água**: Os engenheiros da cidade construíram aquedutos e cisternas extensos para garantir um suprimento constante de água do Rio Varathos, apesar das condições do deserto.
- **Espaços Públicos**: Grandes pátios, banhos públicos e mercados sombreados ajudam os moradores a lidar com o calor do deserto, criando espaços de convivência vitais para a vida social de Varatha.

- **Walls**:  
    Varatha’s defensive walls are a testament to its ancient origins and strategic importance.
    
    - **Inner Wall**: Surrounding the [[Varatha#^e5d873|Old Town]], [[Varatha#^b33dc5|Port District]], and [[Varatha#^78e4f3|Elder Ward]], this is the oldest wall in the city, built during its early days to protect against raiders and desert beasts. It is constructed of sandstone blocks reinforced with magical wards to resist both physical and magical assaults. Guard towers are positioned at regular intervals, manned by the Varathan Rangers.
    - **Outer Walls**: Additional layers of walls segment the newer districts, such as the [[Varatha#^91cfff|High Ward]] and the [[Varatha#^4e8f57|Great Market]], reflecting the city's growth over centuries. These walls are newer, built of sturdier stone and enchanted to withstand siege weaponry.
    - **The Palace Wall**: Surrounding the Palace of the Princes, this wall is the most heavily fortified, with watchtowers, ballista emplacements, and secret entrances known only to the Principal Guard.
- **Aqueducts and Water Systems**:  
    Ensuring water supply in the arid Kesh Desert is one of Varatha's crowning achievements.
    
    - **Aqueducts**: The aqueduct system brings fresh water from the Varathos River to reservoirs located in the [[Varatha#^4e8f57|Great Market]] and [[Varatha#^e5d873|Old Town]].
    - **Cisterns**: Underground cisterns beneath each district store water for times of drought or siege. The largest cistern lies beneath the [[Varatha#^b7fe6c|Hanging Gardens]] in the [[Varatha#^91cfff|High Ward]], doubling as an emergency reserve and an ornamental water feature.
    - **Fountains and Public Baths**: Fountains and communal baths are distributed throughout the city, providing respite from the desert heat. These also serve as social hubs, particularly in the [[Varatha#^dcceb9|Twisting Corridors]] and [[Varatha#^78e4f3|Elder Ward]].
- **Docks and Harbor**:  
    Varatha’s port infrastructure supports its thriving trade with the Keshen Empire and beyond.
    
    - **[[Varatha#^5745ad|The Docks]]**: Located in the [[Varatha#^b33dc5|Port District]], the docks are lined with warehouses, fish markets, and repair yards for ships. Cranes and pulleys allow for efficient loading and unloading of goods.
    - **[[Varatha#^b3cdbe|Lighthouse]]**: A towering lighthouse in the [[Varatha#^78e4f3|Elder Ward]] guides ships safely into the [[Stained Glass Bay]], its magical light visible from miles away.
    - **Shipping Routes**: Carefully mapped trade routes connect [[Varatha]] to [[Idris]], other Keshen settlements, and distant lands along the bay’s coasts.
- **Markets and Commercial Spaces**:
    
    - **The Old Market**: Nestled between the Old Town, Elder Ward, and Port District, this historic market features narrow streets and compact stalls selling artisanal goods, spices, and local produce.
    - **The Jewel of the Desert**: Located in the Great Market district, this expansive bazaar is a hub for mass trade, with large pavilions, auction spaces, and dedicated sections for major commodities like textiles, glassware, and grains.
- **Glassworks and Foundries**:
    
    - **The Melters**: Situated in the Great Market, this industrial zone is home to Varatha’s famed glassmaking industry. Massive furnaces burn day and night, producing everything from stained glass to Dragon Glass. Specialized channels transport raw materials from nearby villages.
    - **Artisan Workshops**: Scattered across the city, small glassmaking workshops handle custom orders and finer craftwork, particularly in the Glassmakers' Quarter.
- **Roads and Walkways**:
    
    - **Paved Roads**: Wide, cobbled streets in the High Ward and Great Market allow for the efficient movement of goods and carriages.
    - **Narrow Streets**: The Twisting Corridors in Old Town are a labyrinth of narrower alleys, suited for pedestrians and small carts. Their design offers shade during the day and vibrant nightlife during the evenings.
    - **Bridges**: Stone bridges span canals and small tributaries of the Varathos River, connecting the districts and ensuring easy navigation of the city.
- **Temples and Religious Infrastructure**:
    
    - **Temple Square**: Located in the Elder Ward, this is a central hub for worship and pilgrimage. The temples here are grand structures, with gardens, courtyards, and shrines dedicated to gods such as At’ar, Bahamut, and Sylvanus.
    - **Hidden Entrances**: Some temples, particularly the one dedicated to At’ar, have concealed chambers and passages rumored to lead to secret vaults and even Abit’s lair.
- **Residential Infrastructure**:
    
    - **Twisting Corridors**: Homes for the middle class, densely packed with shaded courtyards and communal wells.
    - **Hanging Gardens**: In the High Ward, the homes of the wealthy are adorned with lush, vertical gardens, water features, and mosaics of stained glass.
    - **Tumbleweed Village**: Beyond the city walls lies Tumbleweed Village, a sprawling slum of makeshift homes and hidden contraband operations.
- **Academy of Dancing Lights**:  
    A renowned magical academy specializing in Divination, Evocation, and Transmutation, the academy boasts spacious lecture halls, enchanted libraries, and dedicated laboratories. Its towers are visible from almost any point in the city, symbolizing Varatha’s intellectual achievements.

### Defesas
Varatha’s defence system is designed to protect the city’s wealth and resources against the dangers of the Kesh Desert and beyond:

- **Limestone Walls**: Reinforced with desert stone and enchanted by Varathan mages to withstand both physical attacks and magical breaches. 
    
- **Sphinx Guardians**: Enchanted sphinx statues, created by Prince Abit, stand at the city gates and key locations. These sentinels are rumoured to animate when the city faces grave threats, embodying [[Abit]]’s protective influence.
    
- **Varathan Rangers**: The city’s primary guard force, responsible for patrolling Varatha’s streets, walls, and surroundings. Trained to withstand desert conditions, the Rangers are skilled in both urban and open combat, defending Varatha from external threats and maintaining internal peace.
    
- **Principal Guard**: A select, elite militia stationed at the Palace of the Princes. They are tasked with protecting Prince Abit directly and safeguarding highly important locations within Varatha, acting as a special protection force for the prince and city’s key structures.

Varatha tem cinco distritos principais, cada um com propósito e caráter distintos:

1. **Ala dos Anciãos**
    >![[Varatha_06.jpg]]
    > The Elder Ward exudes an air of wisdom and calm, with sprawling temple complexes that fill the district with a serene, spiritual presence. Temple Square is a sacred space, where the gods’ faithful gather to offer prayers, seek guidance, or simply find solace amid the tranquil surroundings. Shrines to At'ar, Bahamut, Sylvanus, and other deities mark Temple Square as a divine meeting ground. Lush greenery from the nearby Elder Woods extends into this ward, giving way to secluded gardens and courtyards where trees and fragrant herbs flourish. The Elder Ward’s iconic Lighthouse stands on a cliff above the Stained Glass Bay, casting a warm glow over the coastline as night falls, guiding sailors home and symbolizing enlightenment for the city’s people. ^78e4f3
    - **Temple Square**: Hub for Varatha’s clergy, featuring temples to At'ar, Bahamut, Sylvanus, and other gods. The temple to At'ar contains a secret entrance to Abit’s lair.

    - **Lighthouse**: Positioned on a cliff overlooking the Stained Glass Bay, accessible by bridge and illuminating the bay’s coastline. ^b3cdbe

### Ativos
- **Dragon Glass**: This rare material, unique to Varatha, is prized for its sharpness and alchemical uses.
	![[dragonglass.jpg]]
- **Ancient Relics and Manuscripts**: Varatha’s academies and guilds hold an invaluable collection of ancient texts and artifacts, preserved by Abit and scholars within the city.
- **Varathan Rangers**: The city’s skilled guard, experienced in both urban and desert terrain defence.

### Trade & Transport
Varatha thrives as a trade hub between the Kesh Desert and other parts of the Keshen Empire. Its docks, markets, and roads facilitate commerce.

### Indústria e Comércio
Varatha’s economy relies on: 
- **Glass and Alchemical Goods**: Stained glass and Dragon Glass are the primary exports, traded throughout the empire and beyond. 
- **Herbs and Exotic Goods**: Close to the Elder Woods, Varatha has access to rare herbs, used both in medicine and alchemy. 
- **Trade Hub**: Located near the desert's edge, Varatha is a stop for caravans crossing the Kesh Desert, making it a thriving center for traders.

### Geografia
Varatha lies at the eastern edge of the Kesh Desert, along the Varathos River delta and close to the Elder Woods. This location offers limited access to fertile land, which the city’s engineers have maximized with irrigation systems.

Varatha has a Mediterranean desert climate, with hot summers, mild winters, and seasonal flooding from the Varathos River.

### Recursos naturais
Varatha’s primary resources include: 
- **Sand and Silica**: Abundant materials essential for its glassmaking. 
- **Medicinal Herbs**: Sourced from the Elder Woods, these herbs are valued across the empire. 
- **Dragon Glass Ore**: Extracted in limited amounts, the ore is refined into the fabled Dragon Glass.

### Agricultura & Indústria
- **Agriculture**: Supported by nearby villages, with Mediterranean-style crops such as olives, figs, and grains.
- **Industry**: Renowned for its glassworks, including stained glass and Dragon Glass production.

### Arquitetura
The architecture is a blend of ancient designs, marked by tall, sandstone buildings with mirrored surfaces that reflect sunlight, earning the city its moniker, the City of Mirrors. Ornate mosaics and stained glass adorn public buildings, while homes are built to maximize ventilation and shade.

### Estrutura da organização
A estrutura da organização define a hierarquia de títulos dentro dela. Ela descreve os principais papéis e suas responsabilidades na organização. Exemplos desses papéis são o Rei de um reino, o Tesoureiro de uma guilda de Mercadores, o Acólito de uma ordem religiosa.

### Agenda Pública
An organization's public agenda describes their goals and motivation behind their actions. This can be the promises of a politician or the mandate of a guild.

### Relações Exteriores
Varatha maintains cordial relations with the [[Império Kesh]], serving as a vital trade hub and cultural landmark. Its autonomy is respected due to its economic importance and Abit’s influence.

### Território
Varatha controls the delta of the Varathos River, the Elder Woods, and nearby villages, forming a bastion of civilization at the edge of the Kesh Desert.
Key areas within Varatha's control include:
- **The city of Varatha**
- **The surrounding Elder Woods**
- **The villages supporting its agricultural and mineral economy**

### Forças Militares
- **Varathan Rangers**: The city’s general guard force, responsible for public safety and external security.
- **Principal Guard**: An elite force stationed at the Palace of the Princes, responsible for protecting Abit and vital locations in the city.

### Cultura
A cultura de uma organização determina a maneira como seus membros/cidadãos percebem e reagem ao mundo ao seu redor. Suas principais crenças e costumes se enquadram na cultura.

### Religião
Quais religiões estão presentes na população/membros da sua organização, como são representadas e que poder detêm? Alguma religião é proibida ou tabu.

### História
Varatha was founded in the first half of the 4th Age, making it an ancient settlement with thousands of years of history. Due to the long span of the ages, Varatha’s origins are largely shrouded in mystery. The city has survived and thrived through countless shifts in the political landscape, the rise and fall of neighbouring empires, and the trials posed by the desert. Its alliance with Emperor Darion Ajakx of the Keshen Empire in the 5th Age solidified Varatha’s unique role, granting it autonomy within the empire and allowing it to develop its distinct identity as a center for trade, knowledge, and artistry.

### Turismo
Varatha attracts a wide range of visitors, including scholars, artisans, and merchants from across the empire:
- **Glass Markets**: Varatha’s reputation as a center for stained glass and Dragon Glass attracts those interested in art and alchemical items. The Glass Markets in the Great Market district showcase the city’s finest craftsmanship and are a major draw for travelers.
- **Temples and Ancient Sites**: Varatha’s ancient temples, particularly those dedicated to gods like At’ar and Bahamut, bring pilgrims from across the empire. These historical and sacred sites make the city an attractive destination for scholars and the devout.

### Educação
The **Academy of Dancing Lights** trains mages in Divination, Evocation, and Transmutation. Basic education is guild-led, with apprenticeships common for artisans.

### Nível tecnológico e científico
Varatha is advanced in glassmaking, alchemical experimentation, and magical education, largely through guild cooperation.

The High Ward is a district of elegance and refinement, home to Varatha’s wealthiest citizens and influential guild members. The Hanging Gardens are a striking feature, cascading with greenery that spills from tiered walls and luxurious courtyards, creating a verdant paradise amid the desert sands. This ward also houses the Academy of Dancing Lights, where aspiring wizards study Divination, Evocation, and Transmutation. Magical luminescence spills from the academy’s spires, adding a mystical allure to the area. The Scented Spire, a wizard’s tower belonging to the enigmatic mage Tulanir, fills the air with subtle aromas of enchanted herbs. Finally, the Barracks stand ready to house Varatha’s elite forces, the Varathan Rangers, with additional training grounds for Keshen soldiers when the empire calls upon its allies. ^91cfff
    - **The Hanging Gardens**: Residential area for Varatha’s elite, with green walls and spacious homes. ^b7fe6c

    - **Barracks**: Home base for the Varathan Rangers and temporary training grounds for Keshen soldiers during wartime.
    - **The Scented Spire**: A wizard’s tower and home to the reclusive mage Tulanir.

A Cidade Velha é o coração da história de Varatha, um distrito onde cada viela estreita e edifício de pedra ecoa o passado antigo da cidade. Os Corredores Serpeantes são um labirinto de ruas vibrantes cheias de atividade movimentada dia e noite, um testamento da resiliência dos varathanos ao longo dos séculos. O Caminho das Cores, uma rua pintada em tons vívidos, explode em vida com mercados, artistas de rua e música ao ar livre. Aqui, o renomado Teatro Estrelar e a taverna Adega da Hydra atraem tanto moradores quanto visitantes. O Palácio dos Príncipes, a peça central e imponente do distrito, ergue-se sobre as ruas estreitas, um lembrete da linhagem real de Varatha. Dentro de seus muros, a Guarda Principal permanece vigilante, protegendo Abit e mantendo a paz em toda a cidade. ^e5d873
    - **Corredores Serpeantes**: Área residencial para a classe média, com ruas estreitas e vibrantes, incluindo o Caminho das Cores, lar do Teatro Estrelar e da taverna Adega da Hydra. ^dcceb9
    - **Palácio dos Príncipes**: Abriga o Conselho da Cidade e a Guarda Principal. Contém uma entrada escondida para o templo de Abit.
    - **Mercado Velho**: Mercado histórico central que conecta a Cidade Velha, o Bairro Ancião e o Distrito Portuário.

O Distrito Portuário é a porta de entrada de Varatha para o mundo — um movimentado centro de comércio e diversidade, onde as vistas e sons do porto nunca cessam. As Docas e Galpoões estão vivas com o movimento de mercadorias e pessoas, o ar rico com o aroma de especiarias e sal. A Guilda dos Navegadores gerencia as operações comerciais aqui, garantindo que as mercadorias de Varatha cheguem a mercados distantes. A Ala dos Marinheiros é uma área animada, que oferece hospedagem para marinheiros e viajantes, repleta do clamor das canções de taverna e do chiado das barracas de comida. Conhecida por sua variedade culinária, esta ala oferece as melhores iguarias locais e sabores importados, tornando-a um caldeirão de culturas e gostos. A taverna Singing Jackaw é um ponto de encontro para marinheiros cansados, aventureiros e contadores de histórias de todo o império. ^b33dc5
    - **Docas e Galpões**: Handles trade and storage for the city, home to the Navigator’s Guild. ^5745ad
    - **Ala dos Marinheiros**: Diverse residential area for sailors and travelers, known for its quality food and the Singing Jackdaw tavern.

The Great Market is Varatha’s bustling commercial center, alive with the sound of haggling merchants and vibrant crowds. This district is a crossroads for traders from across the Keshen Empire, featuring everything from spices to exotic fabrics, rare artifacts, and the prized stained glass for which Varatha is famous. The Jewel of the Desert Market, the heart of the district, is overseen by the Merchant’s Guild, ensuring that trade thrives smoothly. To the north, The Melters, controlled by the Glassmakers’ Guild, house the furnaces and workshops responsible for Varatha’s legendary glass production. Stalls and shops here display everything from alchemical glassware to Dragon Glass, coveted for its razor-sharp quality. The district buzzes with life, with artisans, merchants, and adventurers trading stories and goods alike, adding a vibrant energy to the city’s core. ^4e8f57
    - **Fundição**: Industrial hub where the famous Varathan glass is produced, controlled by the Glassmakers’ Guild.
    - **A Joia do Deserto**: A massive trade hub, dealing in mass-market goods and commodities, led by the Merchant’s Guild.

### Plane of Fire
Fire represents vibrancy, passion, and change. At its worst, it is cruel and wantonly destructive, as the efreet often are, but at its best, fire reflects the light of inspiration, the warmth of compassion, and the flame of desire. 
A blazing sun hangs at the zenith of a golden sky above the Plane of Fire, waxing and waning on a 21-hour cycle. It ranges from white hot at noon to deep red at midnight, so the darkest hours of the plane display a deep red twilight. At noon, the light is nearly blinding. Most business in the City of Brass (see below) takes place during the darker hours.

# Halls of the Infinite
###### Location Type: [[Geographic Location Types#Dimensional plane|Dimensional plane]]

### Parent Location
The parent location defines in which locations area this location is included. If your location is a mountain range the parent location can be a planetary body, a continent or an island depending on how granularly you want to "nest" your locations.

### Ruler / Owner
If this is a landmark, a settlement or a building this can be the actual owner of the structure.

### Owning Rank
Which rank/title has ownership over this location? (i.e. Earldom under Earl, City under Mayor etc)

### Owning Organization
Cities, Guilds, Kingdoms, Religious organizations can own territories, buildings or whole cities. Define here which of your world's organizations claims ownership over this location.

### Organizations Contesting Ownership of the Location

### Alternative Name(s)

### Geography
Describe the location's geographic features. Is the terrain a plain, a mountain or rolling hills? Does it have access to fresh water via a river or a lake? Is it at the edge of a sea or an ocean? You can also talk about the views and natural beauty of the location.

### Ecosystem
Describe the environment, and dynamics that govern the ecosystem of this location. How do the biological organisms and components interact with their physical environment.

### Ecosystem Cycles
How does the ecosystem changes with the passing of seasons (or other cyclical period of time). How do the organisms inhabiting react to this change. Think of migrations, hybernation, hunting or procreating seasons.

### Localized Phenomena
Are there any special natural, weather or super natural phenomena which are distinct to this location? Think the interaction of ferrous earth with lightnings, sandstorms, natural gases or gazers etc.

### History
A short description of the history of the geographic location. Don't forget that you can add all the important events at the location's timeline by creating a timeline and attaching it to the article.

### Tourism
What sort of people visit this location as tourists, what are they eager to see and visit and experience? Where do they stay during their time there.

### Flora & Fauna
Wood from the forests, grain from the fields, sheep in the rolling hills and metals and stone from the bowels of the earth. Natural resources define all the assets that can be found by prospectors, or can be exploited by the population living in, or near by this location

# D&D\Atlas\Edifícios & Marcos\Lareira do Oásis.md

# A Lareira do Oásis
###### Tipo de Local: [[Building Types#Pub / Tavern / Restaurant|Tavern]]


### **The Oasis Hearth**

- A **modest but well-kept** inn, serving as a resting place for **travelers, traders, and mercenaries** passing through Ippan.
    
- Run by **Sahir and Nima Jal**, a middle-aged **human couple** who have lived in Ippan their entire lives.
    
- **Famous for its date wine** and **spiced lamb stew**, local specialties that attract even visitors from Varatha.
    
- A **single-story stone-and-wood building**, built around a **central fire pit**, where guests gather to share news and rumors.
    
- **Has a private back room** often used for **hiring mercenaries or discussing sensitive business**.

### **Notable Patrons of The Oasis Hearth**

**As the only real inn in Ippan, The Oasis Hearth is the center of village life.** Farmers and traders **gather in the evening** to drink and tell stories, while travelers **bring news from beyond the desert.** Some of these regulars stand out more than others.

---

### **1. Bahri "Sandhound" Nalek** _(Retired Bounty Hunter, Now a Drunk)_

- **Race:** Human (Male, Late 50s)
    
- **Occupation:** Former bounty hunter, now a washed-up drunkard.
    
- **Appearance:** Scarred face, salt-and-pepper hair, missing two fingers. Always wears a sun-bleached desert cloak.
    
- **Personality:** Gruff, cynical, and **prone to rambling about his "glory days."**
    
- **Notable Quirks:**
    
    - **Knows the desert better than anyone**—but refuses to go back out.
        
    - Claims he once **tracked a beast that wasn’t from this world** and has **never been the same since.**
        
    - Will **sell information for a drink**, but half of what he says is either **useless or insane**.
        

---

### **2. Hadiya the Whisper** _(Black Market Dealer, Knows More Than She Lets On)_

- **Race:** Halfling (Female, 40s)
    
- **Occupation:** Trader, smuggler, information broker.
    
- **Appearance:** Small, unassuming, always dressed in **simple traveling robes.**
    
- **Personality:** Quiet, observant, speaks in riddles. Never **gives** information—only trades it.
    
- **Notable Quirks:**
    
    - Has **connections to the Thieves' Guild** in Varatha.
        
    - **Deals in rare trinkets**, some of which may be **magical or stolen**.
        
    - Occasionally **disappears from Ippan for weeks at a time**, only to return without explanation.
        
    - If questioned about something dangerous, she’ll respond **with a cryptic warning**, then change the subject.
        

---

### **3. Elder Jaffar** _(Local Mystic, Keeps Old Stories Alive)_

- **Race:** Dragonborn (Bronze, Male, 70s)
    
- **Occupation:** Village elder, storyteller, keeper of traditions.
    
- **Appearance:** Wears **robes embroidered with old Sahzet symbols**, often seen smoking a long pipe.
     
- **Personality:** Wise, patient, but **has a theatrical flair when telling stories.**
    
- **Notable Quirks:**
    
    - **Knows about the lost history of the desert**, including **old ruins, forgotten gods, and strange omens.**
        
    - **Refuses to enter the desert at night**, claiming **"it listens when we speak of it."**
        
    - Speaks of **"The Maw of the Dunes"**—a story dismissed as **folklore by most, but he swears it’s real.**
        
    - Loves to test newcomers with **riddles and games of wit.**
        

---

### **4. Captain Faris Bashad** _(Desert Scout, Imperial Ties)_

- **Race:** Half-Elf (Male, Late 30s)
    
- **Occupation:** Scout for the Kesh Empire, stationed near Ippan.
    
- **Appearance:** Wears **light armor**, imperial insignia pinned to his cloak, always has a dagger within reach.
    
- **Personality:** Stoic, calculating, loyal to the empire—but has a **soft spot for underdogs.**
    
- **Notable Quirks:**
    
    - Often **drinks alone**, watching everyone in the inn like a hawk.
        
    - **Knows more than he lets on** about the Keshen Empire’s **plans for expansion westward**.
        
    - **Can be bribed for information**, but only by **someone he respects.**
        
    - If the players prove themselves capable, he might **offer them work as scouts.**
        

---

### **5. Amal & Yazir Al-Rashid** _(Twin Troublemakers, Always Up to Something)_

- **Race:** Tieflings (Male Twins, 19)
    
- **Occupation:** **Self-proclaimed treasure hunters**, actually just con artists.
    
- **Appearance:** Identical except for **Amal's scar over his left eyebrow**. They wear **brightly colored scarves** and always carry dice.
    
- **Personality:** **Charming but completely unreliable.** Always trying to talk their way out of something.
    
- **Notable Quirks:**
    
    - **Claim to know where hidden ruins are**, but their **maps are usually fake.**
        
    - **Gamble with anyone who will bet**, often **cheating in minor, almost playful ways.**
        
    - Have **a love-hate relationship with Hadiya**, as they both deal in the **black market trade.**
        
    - **Might actually stumble onto something real**—but **no one takes them seriously.**
## Genérico
### Local Pai
O local pai define em qual área de locais esse local está incluído. Se seu local for uma cadeia de montanhas, o local pai pode ser um corpo planetário, um continente ou uma ilha, dependendo do quão granular você deseja  que seus locais estejam vinculados.
### Data de construção
O horário em que o marco/edifício foi construído

### Data em que se tornou uma ruína
O ponto no tempo em que o edifício se tornou uma ruína. Se algo for adicionado a isso, o edifício será marcado como "arruinado".

### Governante / Proprietário
Se for um marco, um assentamento ou um edifício, este pode ser o verdadeiro proprietário da estrutura.

### Classificação de propriedade
Qual classificação/título tem propriedade sobre este local? (por exemplo, Condado sob Conde, Cidade sob Prefeito etc.)

### Organização Proprietária
Cidades, Guildas, Reinos, Organizações religiosas podem possuir territórios, edifícios ou cidades inteiras. Defina aqui qual das organizações do seu mundo reivindica a propriedade sobre este local.

### Organizações contestando a propriedade do local

### Nome(s) Alternativo(s)

### Propósito
Qual é o propósito pretendido do edifício e qual, se diferente, era sua razão original de ser. Procurando mais inspiração? [Check out the How to be a Great GM video on Landmarks](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC1F4eMw3W_rHBfxf9_m1hbw)!

### Alterações
Que tipo de alterações foram feitas no edifício durante o tempo de sua existência e quais propósitos elas atendem?

### Arquitetura
Qual é o estilo de arquitetura usado neste edifício? Qual é a pedra ou madeira usada para as paredes de seus edifícios? Como as pessoas tradicionalmente adornam suas estruturas (por exemplo, cercas de estacas brancas, paredes caiadas com telhados azul-oceano ou portas coloridas). Procurando mais inspiração? [Check out the How to be a Great GM video on Landmarks](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC1F4eMw3W_rHBfxf9_m1hbw)

### História
Uma breve descrição da história do marco ou edifício. Não se esqueça de que você pode adicionar todos os eventos importantes na linha do tempo dos marcos abaixo.

### Turismo
Que tipo de pessoas visitam este local como turistas, o que elas estão ansiosas para ver, visitar e vivenciar? Onde elas ficam durante o tempo que estão lá.

## Quarto

### Salas conectadas
Quais salas são conectadas a esta sala? Lembre-se de que se você entrar em uma sala de uma maneira, não necessariamente poderá voltar pelo mesmo caminho!

### Design
Quais são as dimensões da sala? Ela é quadrada ou retangular? De que cor e de que material são feitos o teto/piso/paredes?

### Entradas
Quais são as entradas (ou possivelmente, apenas saídas) para a sala? Há janelas? Elas estão trancadas, gradeadas, reforçadas?

### Sensorial e aparências
O que as pessoas que entram na sala veem, cheiram, sentem e ouvem. Quanta iluminação está disponível e de onde ela vem? Há um fedor fétido de morte penetrando em suas narinas, ou talvez o som assustador de uma caixa de música perto da janela? Está gelado ou agradavelmente quente?

### Habitantes
Quais pessoas, criaturas ou monstros chamam esta sala de lar ou podem ser encontrados aqui regularmente? Pense em ratos, baratas, Bob, o Bardo, ou Hfthang, o amigável Cthuhlu.

### Conteúdo e Mobília
Que tipo de itens podem ser encontrados na sala? Ferramentas, armas, mobília, dispositivos eletrônicos nas paredes ou quebra-cabeças mágicos exclusivos esperando para serem resolvidos!

### Objetos de valor e tesouros
Que tesouros esperam para serem descobertos nesta sala? Esconderijos de ouro e prata? Obras de arte penduradas nas paredes? Uma estátua feita de esmeralda em um pedestal no meio da sala?

### Perigos e armadilhas
Que tipo de armadilhas e perigos podem ser encontrados na sala? Como eles são ativados ou desativados? Existe algum mecanismo intrincado prendendo as pessoas lá dentro? Ou talvez o chão seja lava!

### Propriedades Especiais
Que tipo de propriedades especiais a sala possui? Dutos de ar, água corrente, alimentado por suporte de vida, é hermético ou um campo mágico de amortecimento? Tem um piso ou teto invisível, as paredes estão irradiando luz ou ele te teletransporta para outra dimensão?

### Ambiente e Efeitos
Pense em efeitos mágicos ou naturais. Temperatura, umidade, pressão, auras, falta de oxigênio, campos antigravitacionais etc.

# Palace of the Last Colossus
###### Location Type: [[Building Types#Palace|Palace]]
![[Palace-of-the-Last-Colossus.jpg]]

## Generic
### Parent Location
The parent location defines in which locations area this location is included. If your location is a mountain range the parent location can be a planetary body, a continent or an island depending on how granularly you want to "nest" your locations.

### Construction Date
The time that the landmark/building was constructed

### Date that Became a Ruin
The point in time which the building became a ruin. If anything is added to this the building will be marked as "ruined".

### Ruler / Owner
If this is a landmark, a settlement or a building this can be the actual owner of the structure.

### Owning Rank
Which rank/title has ownership over this location? (i.e. Earldom under Earl, City under Mayor etc)

### Owning Organization
Cities, Guilds, Kingdoms, Religious organizations can own territories, buildings or whole cities. Define here which of your world's organizations claims ownership over this location.

### Organizations Contesting Ownership of the Location

### Alternative Name(s)

### Purpose
What is the intented purpose of the building and which, if different, was its original reason for being. Looking for more inspiration? [Check out the How to be a Great GM video on Landmarks](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC1F4eMw3W_rHBfxf9_m1hbw)!

### Alterations
What sort of alterations have been done to the building during the time of its existance and which purposes do they serve?

### Architecture
Which is the style of architecture used in this building? Which is the stone or wood used for the walls of its buildings? How do people traditionally adorn their structures (e.g. white picket fences, whitewashed walls with ocean blue roofs or brightly coloured door). Looking for more inspiration? [Check out the How to be a Great GM video on Landmarks](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC1F4eMw3W_rHBfxf9_m1hbw)

### History
A short description of the history of the landmark or building. Don't forget that you can add all the important events at the landsmarks's timeline below.

### Tourism
What sort of people visit this location as tourists, what are they eager to see and visit and experience? Where do they stay during their time there.
## Room

### Connected Rooms
Which rooms are connected to this room? Remember that if you enter a room one way, you can't necessarily go back the same way!

### Design 
Which are the dimensions of the room? Is it square or rectangular? What colour and what material is the ceiling/floor/walls made of?

### Entries
What are the entries (or possibly, exits only) for the room? Are there any windows? Are they locked, barred, reinforced?

### Sensory & Appearances
What do people entering the room see, smell, feel and hear. How much lighting is there available and where is it coming from? Is there the foul stench of death penetrating their nostrils, or perhaps the eerie sound of a music box by the window? Is it icy cold or pleasantly warm?

### Denizens
Which people, creatures or monsters call this room their home or can be found here regularly? Think rats, cockroaches, Bob the Bard or Hfthang the friendly Cthuhlu.

### Contents & Furnishings
What sort of items can be found in the room? Tools, weapons, furniture, electronic devices on the walls, or unique magical puzzles waiting to be solved!

### Valuables & Treasure
What treasures wait to be discovered in this room? Hidden stashes of gold and silver? Works of art hanging off the walls? A statue made of emerald on a pedestal in the middle of the room?

### Hazards & Traps
What kind of traps and hazards can be found in the room? How are they activated or deactivated? Is there any intricate mechanism locking people inside? Or maybe the floor is lava!

### Special Properties
What sort of special properties is the room imbued with? Air ducts, running water, powered by life support, is it airtight or a magic dampening field? Does it have an invisible floor or ceiling, are the walls radiating light, or does it teleport you to another dimension?

### Environment & Effects
Think magical or natural effects. Temperature, humidity, pressure, auras, lack of oxygen, antigravity fields etc.

## Room

### Connected Rooms
Which rooms are connected to this room? Remember that if you enter a room one way, you can't necessarily go back the same way!

### Design 
Which are the dimensions of the room? Is it square or rectangular? What colour and what material is the ceiling/floor/walls made of?

### Entries
What are the entries (or possibly, exits only) for the room? Are there any windows? Are they locked, barred, reinforced?

### Sensory & Appearances
What do people entering the room see, smell, feel and hear. How much lighting is there available and where is it coming from? Is there the foul stench of death penetrating their nostrils, or perhaps the eerie sound of a music box by the window? Is it icy cold or pleasantly warm?

### Denizens
Which people, creatures or monsters call this room their home or can be found here regularly? Think rats, cockroaches, Bob the Bard or Hfthang the friendly Cthuhlu.

### Contents & Furnishings
What sort of items can be found in the room? Tools, weapons, furniture, electronic devices on the walls, or unique magical puzzles waiting to be solved!

### Valuables & Treasure
What treasures wait to be discovered in this room? Hidden stashes of gold and silver? Works of art hanging off the walls? A statue made of emerald on a pedestal in the middle of the room?

### Hazards & Traps
What kind of traps and hazards can be found in the room? How are they activated or deactivated? Is there any intricate mechanism locking people inside? Or maybe the floor is lava!

### Special Properties
What sort of special properties is the room imbued with? Air ducts, running water, powered by life support, is it airtight or a magic dampening field? Does it have an invisible floor or ceiling, are the walls radiating light, or does it teleport you to another dimension?

### Environment & Effects
Think magical or natural effects. Temperature, humidity, pressure, auras, lack of oxygen, antigravity fields etc.

# D&D\Campanhas\01\Handouts\Handout 001.md

# **Bem-vindo a Val**

## **É tempo de guerra. . .**

Oito séculos depois da Grande Guerra e da queda dos Impérios Élficos, o continente de Val se reconfigura em face de novos poderes. Efervescendo no periférico Deserto de Kesh, o Novo Império Kesh, comandado pelo imperador Darion Ajakx, vive sua campanha de expansão e os desafios de uma potência emergente.

30 anos depois da Guerra da União Partida, que dividiu os Campos de Alabastro e anexou as terras de Adama e Epis ao Império Kesh, a conquista do imperador Ajakx se volta para o oeste, sobre o domínio sombrio dos elfos de Sahzet.

Vocês são **cinco** **aventureiros de nível 1** que, por algum motivo, estão no vilarejo de Ippan, a dois dias de Varatha, a segunda maior cidade em Kesh. Na noite do segundo dia do mês de Baran do ano 837 da 5ª Era, a taverna Lareira do Oásis serve como um refúgio do calor escaldante do verão, e os clientes habituais dividem o espaço com visitantes da cidade grande, em clima de festa mas estranheza pela presença de uma caravana imperial.

## **Você pode ser um. . .**
- **Humano**: Você é maioria em Val. Essa é a sua terra. As estradas, fazendas, cidades e castelos foram construídos pelos seus ancestrais, seja desbravando o vasto continente, ou por cima das ruínas de antigas civilizações.
- **Elfo**: Seu povo é herdeiro dos grandes impérios élficos da 4ª Era. Você representa um passado de glória, mas também de dominação. As grandes cidades (das que sboraram) provavelmente foram contruídas pelos seus ancestrais, por mais que os novos impérios as tenham reconfigurado para apagar a hisória élifca.
- **Anão**: Senhores das montanhas, os anões preservaram algumas das comunidades mais antigas em Val. Mestres artesãos e estrategístas, os reinos dos anões se preservaram razoalvelmente neutros nos conflítos externos dos últimos séculos, mas têm tido seus dilemas, montanha adentro.
- **Halfling**: Residentes dos campos e pradarias, o halflings são, na maioria das vezes, amigáveis e adorados por todos.
- **Meio-Elfo**: Fruto de uma época em que elfos e humanos viviam em harmonia, ou originário de um dos poucos lugares que ainda mantêm essa paz, você anda entre dois mundos, mas realmente não pertence a nenhum deles.
- **Draconato:** Familiarizados com a vida em clãs, os draconatos raramente vivem entre outras raças. Com exceção da sua forte presença no Deserto de Kesh, eles são vistos no resto do mundo como símbolo da grandiosidade dracônica ou como monstros selvagens.
- **Meio-Orc**: Marginalizados e temidos, os meio-orcs lutam contra suas heranças de barbaridade e violência, enalquanto tentam se integrar em uma sociedade que raramente os tolera.
- **Tiefling**: Descendente de uma linhagem infernal, você invoca medo e superstição por onde passa. Raros são os lugares onde olhares desdenhosos não se voltam a você, e os poucos da sua raça que atingiram notoriedade o fizeram por uma combinação de esfroço e sorte inomináveis.
- **Gnomo**: Curiosos e engenhosos, os gnomos são pequenos inventores e naturalmente mágicos. Habitantes de florestas antigas ou enclaves escondidos, gnomos formam comunidades unidas, sendo conhecidos por sua criatividade e sua capacidade de enxergar o mundo com entusiasmo.
- **Entre outras opções**!

## **Os Grandes Deuses de Aquarius**

O mundo de Aquarius é lar de inúmeras divindades, de todos os tipos. Abaixo estão os Deuses (bons) mais cultuados em Val:

| Divindade | Alinhamento | Portifólio                       | Domínios (D&D 5E)                  | Símbolos                                                          |
|:--------- |:-----------:|:-------------------------------- |:---------------------------------- |:----------------------------------------------------------------- |
| Aenar*    |      N      | Conhecimento, magia              | Arcana, Knowledge                  | Ânfora com um olho desenhado no centro                            |
| Bahamut   |     LG      | Honra                            | Life, Order, Peace,  War           | Dragão de platina                                                 |
| Corellon  |     CG      | Arte e beleza                    | Arcana, Light, Trickery            | Flor de lótus                                                     |
| Durenos   |     LG      | Criação                          | Forge, Knowledge, War              | Martelo com as pontas esculpidas à semelhança de cabeças de anões |
| Eran      |      N      | Natureza, mares, selva           | Grave, Life, Nature, Tempest       | Coroa de flores, juncos e grãos                                   |
| Ishtar    |     NG      | Compaixão, cura, fertilidade     | Life, Light, Nature                | Estrela brilhante de oito pontas                                  |
| Meliandre |     CG      | Ilusão, lua, noite               | Arcana, Nature, Trickery, Twilight | Lua crescente e uma estela de quatro pontas no meio               |
| Nahir*    |     LN      | Destino, morte                   | Death, Grave, Twilight             | Máscara branca com detalhes em ouro                               |
| Nauron    |     NG      | Luz, redenção                    | Life, Light, War                   | Mão dourada, palma para cima, com um sol nascente acima dela      |
| Or        |     CN      | Batalha, competição, tempestades | Tempest, War                       | Lança com um raio na ponta                                        |
| Vin       |     LN      | Civilização, justiça             | Knowledge, Order, Peace            | Manopla segurando a balança da justiça                            |
| Zimo      |     CN      | Chance, liberdade, sorte         | Nature, Trickery                   | Bota com uma adaga enfiada                                        |

* Aenar, deusa da magia e Nahir, deusa da morte, são menos cultuadas pelas massas, mas sim por grupos específicos, como magos ou sacerdotes funerários, por exemplo.

# D&D\D&D Rules\Appendices\Conditions.md

# Appendix A: Conditions
---
Conditions alter a creature's capabilities in a variety of ways and can arise as a result of a spell, a class feature, a monster's attack, or other effect. Most conditions, such as [[Conditions#Blinded|blinded]], are impairments, but a few, such as [[Conditions#Invisible|invisible]], can be advantageous.

A condition lasts either until it is countered (the [[Conditions#Prone|prone]] condition is countered by standing up, for example) or for a duration specified by the effect that imposed the condition.

If multiple effects impose the same condition on a creature, each instance of the condition has its own duration, but the condition's effects don't get worse. A creature either has a condition or doesn't.

The following definitions specify what happens to a creature while it is subjected to a condition.

## Blinded
---
-   A blinded creature can't see and automatically fails any ability check that requires sight.
-   Attack rolls against the creature have advantage, and the creature's attack rolls have disadvantage.

## Charmed
---
-   A charmed creature can't attack the charmer or target the charmer with harmful abilities or magical effects.
-   The charmer has advantage on any ability check to interact socially with the creature.

## Deafened
---
-   A deafened creature can't hear and automatically fails any ability check that requires hearing.

## Exhaustion
---
Some special abilities and environmental hazards, such as starvation and the long-term effects of freezing or scorching temperatures, can lead to a special condition called exhaustion. Exhaustion is measured in six levels. An effect can give a creature one or more levels of exhaustion, as specified in the effect's description.

| Level | Effect                         |
|:-----:| ------------------------------ |
| 1     | Disadvantage on ability checks |
| 2     | Speed halved |
| 3     | Disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws 
| 4     | Hit point maximum halved |
| 5     | Speed reduced to 0 |
| 6     | Death |

If an already exhausted creature suffers another effect that causes exhaustion, its current level of exhaustion increases by the amount specified in the effect's description.

A creature suffers the effect of its current level of exhaustion as well as all lower levels. For example, a creature suffering level 2 exhaustion has its speed halved and has disadvantage on ability checks.

An effect that removes exhaustion reduces its level as specified in the effect's description, with all exhaustion effects ending if a creature's exhaustion level is reduced below 1.  
Finishing a long rest reduces a creature's exhaustion level by 1, provided that the creature has also ingested some food and drink. Also, being raised from the dead reduces a creature’s exhaustion level by 1.

## Frightened
---
-   A frightened creature has disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls while the source of its fear is within line of sight.
-   The creature can't willingly move closer to the source of its fear.

## Grappled
---
-   A grappled creature's speed becomes 0, and it can't benefit from any bonus to its speed.
-   The condition ends if the grappler is [[Conditions#Incapacitated|incapacitated]] (see the condition).
-   The condition also ends if an effect removes the grappled creature from the reach of the grappler or grappling effect, such as when a creature is hurled away by the [[Thunderwave|thunderwave]] spell.

## Incapacitated
---
-   An incapacitated creature can't take actions or reactions.

## Invisible
---
-   An invisible creature is impossible to see without the aid of magic or a special sense. For the purpose of hiding, the creature is heavily obscured. The creature's location can be detected by any noise it makes or any tracks it leaves.
-   Attack rolls against the creature have disadvantage, and the creature's attack rolls have advantage.

## Paralyzed
---
-   A paralyzed creature is [[Conditions#Incapacitated|incapacitated]] (see the condition) and can't move or speak.
-   The creature automatically fails Strength and Dexterity saving throws. Attack rolls against the creature have advantage.
-   Any attack that hits the creature is a critical hit if the attacker is within 5 feet of the creature.

## Petrified
---
-   A petrified creature is transformed, along with any nonmagical object it is wearing or carrying, into a solid inanimate substance (usually stone). Its weight increases by a factor of ten, and it ceases aging.
-   The creature is [[Conditions#Incapacitated|incapacitated]] (see the condition), can't move or speak, and is unaware of its surroundings.
-   Attack rolls against the creature have advantage.
-   The creature automatically fails Strength and Dexterity saving throws.
-   The creature has resistance to all damage.
-   The creature is immune to poison and disease, although a poison or disease already in its system is suspended, not neutralized.

## Poisoned
---
-   A poisoned creature has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

## Prone
---
-   A prone creature's only movement option is to crawl, unless it stands up and thereby ends the condition.
-   The creature has disadvantage on attack rolls.
-   An attack roll against the creature has advantage if the attacker is within 5 feet of the creature. Otherwise, the attack roll has disadvantage.

## Restrained
---
-   A restrained creature's speed becomes 0, and it can't benefit from any bonus to its speed.
-   Attack rolls against the creature have advantage, and the creature's attack rolls have disadvantage.
-   The creature has disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws.

## Stunned
---
-   A stunned creature is [[Conditions#Incapacitated|incapacitated]] (see the condition), can't move, and can speak only falteringly.
-   The creature automatically fails Strength and Dexterity saving throws.
-   Attack rolls against the creature have advantage.

## Unconscious
---
-   An unconscious creature is [[Conditions#Incapacitated|incapacitated]], can't move or speak, and is unaware of its surroundings.
-   The creature drops whatever it's holding and falls [[Conditions#Prone|prone]].
-   The creature automatically fails Strength and Dexterity saving throws.
-   Attack rolls against the creature have advantage.
-   Any attack that hits the creature is a critical hit if the attacker is within 5 feet of the creature.
